articles.headline: Wall Street Paychecks May Wither
articles.snippet: Pay in the financial industry was excessively high around 1930 and from the mid-1990s until 2006, according to two economists, but may be set to fall.
articles.abstract: Pay in the financial industry was excessively high around 1930 and from the mid-1990s until 2006, according to two economists, but may be set to fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is one thing when the best-paid people seem to be the smartest and the most accomplished. Those who make much less may not like it, but the differential seems understandable. It is another thing when those people are shown to have committed huge blunders that would have driven their companies out of business, and them into the unemployment line, but for government bailouts.

articles.headline: Sweden’s Fix for Banks: Nationalize Them
articles.snippet: Sweden’s experience with reviving a failed banking system might provide a model for the United States.
articles.abstract: Sweden’s experience with reviving a failed banking system might provide a model for the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Swedes have a simple message to the Americans: Bite the bullet and nationalize.

articles.headline: Smaller Banks’ Losses Expected to Bring Mergers
articles.snippet: Some federal money is coming with a condition that smaller banks seek to merge with larger institutions.
articles.abstract: Some federal money is coming with a condition that smaller banks seek to merge with larger institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government may view Bank of America and Citigroup as too big to fail, and dozens of smaller banks may soon find that size matters for them as well.

articles.headline: Two Sides of a Border: One Violent, One Peaceful
articles.snippet: El Paso is one of the safest cities in the U.S., but just across the Rio Grande violence is ripping apart Ciudad Juárez.
articles.abstract: El Paso is one of the safest cities in the U.S., but just across the Rio Grande violence is ripping apart Ciudad Juárez.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL PASO  Every day, as she gets off a bus in Mexico and crosses the border to go to work in downtown El Paso, Edith Escobedo says she feels a sense of relief. For at least the next eight hours, she says to herself, she is safe from the violence ripping apart Ciudad Juárez.

articles.headline: Geithner Hints at Harder Line on China Trade
articles.snippet: Timothy F. Geithner stated that the president believed that China was “manipulating” its currency.
articles.abstract: Timothy F. Geithner stated that the president believed that China was “manipulating” its currency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Timothy F. Geithner, who moved closer to confirmation as Treasury secretary on Thursday, told senators that President Obama believed China was “manipulating” its currency, suggesting a more confrontational stance toward that country than under the Bush administration.

articles.headline: Freed by the U.S., Saudi Becomes a Qaeda Chief
articles.snippet: The emergence of a former Guantánamo Bay detainee as leader of Al Qaeda’s Yemeni branch underscores the potential complications of closing the site.
articles.abstract: The emergence of a former Guantánamo Bay detainee as leader of Al Qaeda’s Yemeni branch underscores the potential complications of closing the site.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The emergence of a former Guantánamo Bay detainee as the deputy leader of Al Qaeda’s Yemeni branch has underscored the potential complications in carrying out the executive order President Obama signed Thursday that the detention center be shut down within a year.

articles.headline: China’s Route Forward
articles.snippet: China is starting to spend hundreds of billions of dollars on infrastructure projects, fearing that widespread joblessness could lead to social unrest.
articles.abstract: China is starting to spend hundreds of billions of dollars on infrastructure projects, fearing that widespread joblessness could lead to social unrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China  In an effort to hold back the domestic effects of the global downturn, China is starting to spend hundreds of billions of dollars on new highways, railroads and other infrastructure projects.

articles.headline: Thain Resigns Amid Losses at Bank of America
articles.snippet: John A. Thain, the former chief of Merrill Lynch, was said to no longer have the trust of the head of Bank of America.
articles.abstract: John A. Thain, the former chief of Merrill Lynch, was said to no longer have the trust of the head of Bank of America.
articles.lead_paragraph: His Wall Street pedigree seems impeccable. A top job at Goldman Sachs. The chief of the New York Stock Exchange. Finally, the reins of the stock market’s “thundering herd,” Merrill Lynch.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Louise Story

articles.headline: F.D.A. Approves a Stem Cell Trial
articles.snippet: The government will allow the world’s first test in people of a therapy derived from human embryonic stem cells.
articles.abstract: The government will allow the world’s first test in people of a therapy derived from human embryonic stem cells.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a research milestone, the federal government will allow the world’s first test in people of a therapy derived from human embryonic stem cells.
